content.webTitle: Police investigation of DJ sex offender Ray Teret shown in BBC2 documentary

fields.headline: Police investigation of DJ sex offender Ray Teret shown in BBC2 documentary
fields.bodyText: A new BBC2 documentary will follow in forensic detail the police investigation and subsequent conviction of a former DJ and friend of Jimmy Savile who was jailed for 25 years for a string of historical sex offences. The three-part series will include harrowing interviews with victims of former Radio Caroline DJ, Ray Teret, who was sentenced last year for the rape and indecent assault of girls in Manchester in the 1960s and 1970s. Detectives in the case told of the “thrill” when wallpaper in his former flat was peeled away to reveal the names of girls graffitied on the wall, corroborating victims’ evidence given to police half a century later. It also includes footage of the first police interview given by Cathy Hymas, one of the first women to come forward, who was 12 when she first met Teret. Hymas told police she found herself getting “churned up” whenever she saw Savile on television because “the mannerisms and stuff reminds me of Teret”. “I took my friend to see this man, he had me doing sex while she was there like, you know, this is what you do. When he’d finished I just went home, I just felt so embarrassed,” said Hymas, breaking down in tears. “I thought Teret was my friend, I trusted him as a friend.” The series, called The Detectives, was filmed over two years at a specialist unit to investigate sex offences set up by Greater Manchester police three years ago. It includes a number of cases including Paul Fenner, a Wigan man who was jailed in 2013 for raping a 13-year-old girl on her way to school, and briefly features former TV weatherman Fred Talbot, who was jailed earlier this year for five years for indecently assaulting two schoolboys when he was a teacher. Teret initially denied the allegations, telling detectives in an early interview: “I’ve got my mouth open, nothing has ever happened like that. I have never had sex with underage girls.” The series director, James Newton, said: “I think he was playing games with us when we first filmed him in custody. He wants to have control. We did talk to him a little bit. He was an odd man, a really odd man.” Executive producer Colin Barr, talking at the programme launch on Monday, said: “It is really difficult to get programmes on a subject like this on to television. It is dark and grim and all of those things. I hope by having a series like this, it has the narrative twists … that people will want to come back and see what happens next.” Det Sgt Carol Barlow, one of the officers in charge of the Teret investigation, said: “This isn’t a drama, it’s real life. I can’t tell you the thrill the incident team had when ‘oh my god, we have got the evidence [on Teret], we have got something that corroborates that those girls were in that flat’. It was a very uplifting moment.” She said historical offences against celebrities were “pretty much the flavour of the moment and there are two categories [of responses]. There are those that think it’s a great thing but sadly there are those whose opinion is well, it was all so long ago, why haven’t they moved on, what’s their motive, are they lying?” Barlow added: “From speaking to some of the victims … the hurt it has caused them is terrible and I really hope this programme might promote some thought into the long term effect that an event like that has on a child and how it forms their adulthood.” The series will be shown on BBC2 on three consecutive nights, beginning this Sunday. Det Supt Jon Chadwick, who set up the new Manchester unit, said he hoped the series would encourage more women who had been attacked to come to the police. In the past three years, the number of rapes reported to the Greater Manchester force has increased by 130%. “Policing gets a lot of bad press, it would be very easy to misquote us out of context,” said Chadwick. “Cops are human beings under pressure, they say the wrong thing now and again, including myself.”
